config.question: Which of the following most likely accounts for the large number of women workers in the mechanized textile mills in New England?

choices.content: spinning and weaving was traditionally women’s work
the absence of a substantial male workforce
the undemanding nature of the work
formation of strong women workers’ unions

answer_3.response: As late as 1820, about two-thirds of the clothing Americans wore was made entirely in households by female family members, who adopted the “putting-out” system of manufacturing. The shift in textile manufacture from domestic to factory production also shifted the locus of women's economic activity. As the New England textile industry grew, the putting-out system declined.
